title: Symphony X
text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2021}}
{{About||symphonies|Symphony 10 (disambiguation){{!}}Symphony No. 10|their self-titled debut album|Symphony X (album)}}

'''Symphony X''' is an American [[progressive metal]] band from [[Middletown, New Jersey]]. Founded in 1994, the band consists of guitarist [[Michael Romeo]], keyboardist [[Michael Pinnella]], drummer [[Jason Rullo]], lead vocalist [[Russell Allen]] and bassist [[Michael Lepond]].

They achieved some commercial success with the 2007 album ''[[Paradise Lost (Symphony X album)|Paradise Lost]]'' and the 2011 album ''[[Iconoclast (Symphony X album)|Iconoclast]]'', which reached number 76 on the [[Billboard 200]]. Romeo explained the band's name in a 2008 interview; "So, you know, the music we were coming up with had the keyboard thing and the guitar, and some classical elements, so the word 'Symphony' came up and, so the dramatic thing, you know? So then, somebody said 'Symphony X' and we were like, 'yeah, that's cool' it is that kinda thing, and the 'X' is the unknown and all the other stuff we do."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theheaviestmatteroftheuniverse.com/2009/01/16/interview-with-michael-romeo-of-symphony-x-4408/|title=Interview with Michael Romeo of Symphony X|date=April 4, 2008|website=Theheaviestmatteroftheuniverse.com|access-date=March 22, 2020}}</ref>

==History==
===''Symphony X'' and ''The Damnation Game'' (1994−1995)===
In early 1994 [[Michael Romeo]] (formerly of the bands Phantom's Opera and Gemini) recorded a studio album titled ''[[The Dark Chapter]]'', which featured himself and keyboard player [[Michael Pinnella]].<ref name="alloutguitar1">{{cite web|url=http://www.alloutguitar.com/interview/artists_and_bands/michael_romeo_interview_%E2%80%93_perfect_symphony_part_one_1970039s_2000 |title=A Perfect Symphony Part One: 1970's to 2000 |access-date=February 18, 2009 |author=Edwards, Owen |date=March 4, 2008 |website=Alloutguitar.com |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090201135330/http://alloutguitar.com/interview/artists_and_bands/michael_romeo_interview_%E2%80%93_perfect_symphony_part_one_1970039s_2000 |archive-date=February 1, 2009 }}</ref> The tape attracted a fair share of attention, particularly in [[Japan]].<ref name="alloutguitar1"/> Romeo then recruited bassist [[Thomas Miller (bassist)|Thomas Miller]], drummer [[Jason Rullo]], and vocalist [[Rod Tyler]].<ref name="progmetalblog">{{cite web | url = http://progmetalblog.blogspot.com/2007/01/symphony-x.html | title = Symphony X | access-date = February 18, 2009 | work = PROG METAL BLOG | publisher = [[blogspot.com]] | date = January 9, 2007}}</ref> Their [[Symphony X (album)|self-titled debut album]] was recorded in the same year, and released to a positive reception in Japan by the now-defunct record company Zero Corporation.<ref name="officialromeo">{{cite web | url = http://www.symphonyx.com/michael_romeo.html | title = Symphony X Band Info: Members: Michael Romeo | access-date = February 18, 2009 | publisher = symphonyx.com | date = July 5, 2005 | url-status = dead | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110721164229/http://www.symphonyx.com/michael_romeo.html | archive-date = July 21, 2011}}</ref> The band's second studio album, ''[[The Damnation Game (album)|The Damnation Game]]'', followed six months later. Singer Rod Tyler had left the band by then and was replaced by current singer [[Russell Allen]].<ref name="FAQ-7">{{cite web | url = http://www.symphonyx.com/site/faq/#why-did-rod-and-jason-and-tom-walling-leave-the-band-how-did-you-find-russell | title = Official Symphony X FAQ: Why did Rod and Jason, and Tom Walling leave the band? How did you find Russell? | access-date = February 18, 2009 | publisher = symphonyx.com | date = September 2003}}</ref>

===''The Divine Wings Of Tragedy'' and ''Twilight In Olympus'' (1996−1998)===
''[[The Divine Wings of Tragedy]]'' was the album that first gave Symphony X exposure in metal circles. It took a considerable time to record the album, with the recording sessions taking place in 1996, and the album was released late in the year.

At the end of 1997 and for part of the next year, Jason Rullo, their drummer, had to stay away from the band in order to solve personal issues. He was temporarily replaced by Thomas Walling. Even with a temporary drummer, the band recorded ''[[Twilight in Olympus]]'', released in early 1998. That year also saw the first live performances from the band, which by then had already gathered many fans from around the globe. Their first official show happened in 1998, in [[Japan]]. It was soon followed by a world tour. Bassist Thomas Miller left the band and was replaced by [[Michael Lepond]] in that year.

A compilation album, ''[[Prelude to the Millennium]]'', was released by the end of 1998. As an extra, it featured a second version of the song "Masquerade" from the first album, with Russell Allen on vocals.

===''V: The New Mythology Suite'' and ''The Odyssey'' (1999−2005)===
Jason Rullo returned to the drums for the band's fifth album, ''[[V – The New Mythology Suite|V: The New Mythology Suite]]'', released in 2000. It was the band's first release on major progressive label [[InsideOut Music]]. The album was their first [[concept album]], dealing with the [[myth]] of [[Atlantis]]. The album features classics such as "Evolution (The Grand Design)", "Communion and the Oracle", "Egypt" and the mini-suite "Rediscovery", and includes pieces of classical music.

The band went on a European and South American tour shortly after its release and recorded their first live album, ''[[Live on the Edge of Forever]]''.

In 2002, the band released ''[[The Odyssey (album)|The Odyssey]]'', an album prominently featuring a 24-minute-long musical interpretation of the [[Homer]]ic [[Epic poetry|epic]], the [[Odyssey]].

In 2005 Symphony X was featured on [[Gigantour]], a summer festival headlined by [[Megadeth]] with [[Dream Theater]], [[Nevermore]] and [[Anthrax (American band)|Anthrax]]. Two Symphony X songs from the tour, "Inferno" and "Of Sins and Shadows", are featured on the Gigantour DVD and CD-set, released in September 2006.<ref name="blogcritics">{{cite web | url = http://blogcritics.org/archives/2006/08/23/090555.php | title = DVD Review: Gigantour 2005 | access-date = February 18, 2009 | author = Beaumont, Christopher | date = August 23, 2006 | work = Blogcritics Magazine | publisher = blogcritics.org | url-status = dead | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090426041915/http://blogcritics.org/archives/2006/08/23/090555.php | archive-date = April 26, 2009}}</ref><ref name="amazon2">{{cite web | url = https://www.amazon.com/Gigantour-Various-Artists/dp/B000G8NY4A | title = Gigantour: Various Artists | website = Amazon | access-date = February 18, 2009 | date = September 5, 2006}}</ref>

===''Paradise Lost'' (2006–2010)===
[[Image:Sx-russell-3-small.JPG|thumb|right|Lead vocalist Russell Allen performing at a concert in [[San Juan, Puerto Rico]] on May 27, 2007.]]
The band's album ''[[Paradise Lost (Symphony X album)|Paradise Lost]]'', a concept album loosely inspired by [[John Milton]]'s [[Paradise Lost|epic poem of the same name]], was recorded in Romeo's studio throughout 2006, delayed numerous times and released finally worldwide on June 26, 2007. The band claimed this work had darker themes musically.<ref name="getreadytorock">{{cite web | url = http://www.getreadytorock.com/10questions/symphony_x.htm | title = 10 Questions with Symphony X | access-date = February 18, 2009 | author = Ritchie, Jason | year = 2007 | publisher = getreadytorock.com}}</ref> The album included a special DVD of footage shot by the band throughout their history, available in [[f.y.e.|FYE]] stores.<ref name="myspace">{{cite web | url = http://blogs.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=blog.view&friendID=54655229&blogID=281611759 | title = Bonus dvd, tour dates, and sales figures, oh my! | access-date = February 18, 2009 | author = Jax VH, Symphony X Internet representative | date = June 27, 2007 | work = Symphony X MySpace Blog | publisher = [[myspace.com]] | url-status = dead | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20121104165526/http://www.myspace.com/symphonyx/blog/281611759 | archive-date = November 4, 2012}}</ref> The release coincided with a 14-month world tour, including a tour through all of Europe with [[Dream Theater]] in the fall of 2007.<ref name="plpress">{{cite web | url = http://www.symphonyx.com/news.html#plpress | title = Official ''Paradise Lost'' Press Release | access-date = February 18, 2009 | publisher = symphonyx.com | date = March 26, 2007 | url-status = dead | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090220140930/http://symphonyx.com/news.html#plpress | archive-date = February 20, 2009}}</ref> The band also revealed plans to perform in Japan and other Asian countries, as well as appear for the first time ever in Russia, India, and the Middle East.<ref name="plpress"/>

''Paradise Lost'' debuted at number 123 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] album chart in the United States, selling 6,300 copies in its first week. The record also debuted at number 1 on the [[Top Heatseekers]] Chart.<ref name="billboard">{{cite web | url = {{BillboardURLbyName|artist=symphony x|chart=all}} | title = ''Paradise Lost'' reaches 1 on Billboard Heatseekers Chart | access-date = February 18, 2009 | publisher = [[billboard.com]] |date=July 2007}}</ref><ref name="sales">{{cite web | url = http://www.symphonyx.com/news.html#sales | title = ''Paradise Lost'' Sales | access-date = February 18, 2009 | publisher = symphonyx.com | date = July 13, 2007 | url-status = dead | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090220140930/http://symphonyx.com/news.html#sales | archive-date = February 20, 2009}}</ref>

Symphony X released their first [[music video]] for the song "Serpent's Kiss" on July 28, 2007.<ref name="metalunderground">{{cite web | url = http://www.metalunderground.com/news/details.cfm?newsid=27803 | title = Watch Symphony X's 'Serpent's Kiss' Video Online | access-date = February 18, 2009 | publisher = metalunderground.com | date = July 28, 2007}}</ref> It was followed by a video for "Set the World on Fire", released on January 11, 2008.<ref name="headbangersblog">{{cite web | url = http://headbangersblog.mtv.com/2008/01/11/video-premiere-symphony-xs-set-the-world-on-fire/ | title = Video Premiere: Symphony X's 'Set the World on Fire' | access-date = February 18, 2009 | work = Headbangers Blog | publisher = MTV Networks | date = January 11, 2008}}</ref> The band toured North and South America from October to November 2008, and toured Asia in February 2009.

===''Iconoclast'' (2011–2013)===
On March 1, 2010, an update on the Symphony X official website announced, that the band had recorded most of their next album and that Romeo and Allen were working on lyrics; Romeo was getting ready to start doing tracking for the album.<ref name="metalunderground2">{{cite web|url=http://www.metalunderground.com/news/details.cfm?newsid=40065|title=Symphony X Plans North East Shows In Support Of 5.1 Special Edition of "Paradise Lost"|date=November 6, 2008|website=Metalunderground.com|access-date=February 18, 2009}}</ref><ref name="metalunderground3">{{cite web|url=http://www.metalunderground.com/news/details.cfm?newsid=38492|title=Symphony X Announces South American Tour Dates|website=Metalunderground.com|date=August 20, 2008|access-date=February 18, 2009}}</ref><ref name="blabbermouth">{{cite web|url=http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=109108|archive-url=https://archive.today/20130104133050/http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=109108|url-status=dead|archive-date=January 4, 2013|title=Symphony X: More Asian Tour Details Revealed|date=November 18, 2008|website=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|access-date=February 18, 2009}}</ref> The album's name and lyrical concept were revealed on January 29, 2011 in an interview by DJ JC Green of Metal Messiah Radio's "Heavy Metal Thunder" show with Russell Allen: the follow-up to ''Paradise Lost'' will be titled ''[[Iconoclast (Symphony X album)|Iconoclast]]'' and will have its lyrics centered around "machines taking over everything and all this technology we put our society into pretty much being our demise."<ref name="Blabbermouth.net">{{cite web|title=Symphony X: New Album Title, Lyrical Concept Revealed|url=http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=153030|website=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|access-date=January 29, 2011|date=January 29, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110203004723/http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=153030|archive-date=February 3, 2011|url-status=dead}}</ref> On March 25, 2011, it was announced on the Nuclear Blast website and Blabbermouth.net, that the new Symphony X album, ''Iconoclast'', would be released in Europe on June 17 and in North America on June 21,<ref name="Nuclear Blast">{{Cite web|url=https://www.nuclearblast.de/en/label/music/band/discography/details/314929.71100.iconoclast.html|title=Iconoclast by SYMPHONY X - info and shop at Nuclear Blast - Nuclear Blast|website=Nuclearblast.de}}</ref> as a Standard Edition as well as a 2-CD Digipack. ''Iconoclast'' debuted at number 76 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] album chart in the United States, selling more than 7,300 copies in its first week. The record also debuted at number 7 on the Top Hard Rock Chart, number 19 on the [[Rock Songs|Top Rock]] Chart and number 13 on the [[Independent Albums|Top Independent]] Chart.<ref name="billboard100">{{cite web | url = {{BillboardURLbyName|artist=symphony x|chart=all}} | title = ''Iconoclast chart position'' | access-date = June 30, 2011 | publisher = [[billboard.com]] |date=June 2011}}</ref><ref name="recordsales">{{cite web | url = http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=160060 | title = ''Iconoclast cracks US Top 100'' Sales | access-date = June 30, 2011 | publisher = blabbermouth.net | date = June 30, 2011 }}{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref> The album showcases the highest chart position and the most first-week sales in the band's history.

On February 25, 2011, Symphony X played the first show of their 2011 tour in [[Stuttgart]], Germany, where they performed two songs from ''Iconoclast'': "End of Innocence" and "Dehumanized". Some days later, in [[Antwerp]], Belgium, they performed yet another new song, "Heretic". During their show in London, England, the band debuted another new song titled "Prometheus".

On February 27, 2013, it was announced that, during the previous week, drummer [[Jason Rullo]] was admitted to hospital for heart failure. Jason spent a week in hospital, and was released after some days. He then started a rehab program that took a minimum of 3–6 months under doctors' care.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.symphonyx.com/site/news/jason-rullo/|title=Jason Rullo|access-date=May 12, 2013 |work=SymphonyX.com}}</ref> [[John Macaluso]] joined them on tour for their South American and European dates, until Jason Rullo was able to fully recover.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.symphonyx.com/site/news/update-on-jason-and-the-upcoming-shows/|title=Update on Jason and the upcoming shows|access-date=May 12, 2013 |website=SymphonyX.com}}</ref>

===''Underworld'' and band hiatus (2015–2019)===
[[File:Symphony X 2016a.jpg|thumb|Symphony X at Israel, 2016]]
The band is working on releasing a second fan club CD. Michael Romeo said it will be another collection of demo tunes and other rare material, and may also include a bit of content created just for the release, along the lines of MJR's Star Wars tune on the first fan club CD, Rarities and Demos, which has since sold out of its first pressing. SXW, the band's revamped fan club, has relaunched and is now active.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.symphonyx.com/site/news/new-cd-heavy-montreal-and-more/|title=New cd, Heavy Montreal, and more..|work=symphonyx.com}}</ref>

The band began recording the drum tracks for the new album on September 9, 2014, and planned to release the complete recording by the spring of 2015.<ref name=blabber>{{cite web|title=Symphony X To Begin Recording New Album This Week|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/symphony-x-to-begin-recording-new-album-this-week/#uyW8cyfFMm1f5szq.99|website=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|access-date=September 13, 2014|date=September 8, 2014}}</ref> [[Michael Lepond]] stated they had ten songs written and that the album would contain either nine or all ten of them.<ref name=blabber/> He also stated all lyrics and instrumental tracks were composed and ready to be brought together, and that the album would be less heavy than ''Iconoclast'': "If I had to compare, I would say that it's a combination of ''The Odyssey'' and ''Paradise Lost'' — something in there. It has a lot of classic Symphony X elements in it, which I think a lot of our fans were missing for a few years. So I think our fans will really like this one. It really just focuses on solid songwriting."<ref name=blabber/>

As of December 11, 2014, recording of the drums, lead vocals, rhythm guitar, and bass were complete. With the keyboards, guitar solos, background vocals, and some miscellaneous odds and ends being done in the coming weeks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.symphonyx.com/site/news/a-holiday-gift-news-on-the-new-cd/|title=A holiday gift – news on the new cd|work=symphonyx.com}}</ref> On April 10, 2015 the band announced the mixing and mastering of the new album was complete. On May 18, 2015, the band announced the title of the album would be titled ''[[Underworld (Symphony X album)|Underworld]]'', and a release date of July 24, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|title=The new album, titled "Underworld", will be out in July!|url=http://www.symphonyx.com/site/news/the-new-album-titled-underworld-will-be-out-in-july/|website=Symphony X Official Website|access-date= May 18, 2015}}</ref> The first single from the album, "''Nevermore''", premiered on May 22, 2015.<ref>Archived at [https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211211/_z3AHbjeb1U Ghostarchive]{{cbignore}} and the [https://web.archive.org/web/20150821095950/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_z3AHbjeb1U&feature=youtu.be Wayback Machine]{{cbignore}}: {{cite AV media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_z3AHbjeb1U|title=SYMPHONY X - Nevermore (OFFICIAL LYRIC VIDEO)|date=May 22, 2015|publisher=[[YouTube]]}}{{cbignore}}</ref> The band released the second single, ''"Without You"'', on June 19, 2015, and was made available for digital download.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/symphony-x-releases-without-you-digital-single-lyric-video-available/|title=Symphony X Releases 'Without You' Digital Single; Lyric Video Available - Blabbermouth.net|work=BLABBERMOUTH.NET|date=June 19, 2015}}</ref>

According to singer [[Russell Allen]], the band entered a short hiatus during 2017 in which they did not perform, due in part to his commitment to [[Adrenaline Mob]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/russell-allen-theres-no-future-plans-for-symphony-x-at-this-time/|title=RUSSELL ALLEN: 'There's No Future Plans For SYMPHONY X At This Time'|date=May 1, 2017|work=BLABBERMOUTH.NET|access-date=February 14, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> although it was announced during a January 2018 interview with Metal Nation that the band had plans to get together in the following months and begin writing a follow up to Underworld.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.blabbermouth.net/news/symphony-x-to-begin-work-on-follow-up-to-underworld/|title=SYMPHONY X To Begin Work On Follow-Up To 'Underworld'|date=January 16, 2018|website=Blabbermouth.net|access-date=March 22, 2020}}</ref> On July 14, 2017, Adrenaline Mob was involved in a serious vehicular accident, which resulted in severe injuries for Allen and the death of the band's bassist and their tour manager.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.gainesville.com/news/20170714/truck-slams-into-adrenaline-mobs-rv-on-i-75|title=Truck slams into Adrenaline Mob's RV on I-75|last=Miller|first=Austin L.|access-date=February 14, 2018|language=en}}</ref> In July 2018, according to [[Michael Romeo]], the band hopes to re-group and make another album, but also said that he was giving [[Russell Allen]] some time and space after dealing with the aftermath of the accident, and also his touring commitments with [[Trans-Siberian Orchestra]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.blabbermouth.net/news/symphony-x-will-regroup-at-some-point-to-begin-work-on-follow-up-to-underworld/|title=SYMPHONY X Will Regroup 'At Some Point' To Begin Work On Follow-Up To 'Underworld'|date=July 2, 2018|website=Blabbermouth.net}}</ref> In June 2019, Romeo was considering to make their tenth album after they're done touring in August 2019.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://metalinjection.net/upcoming-releases/symphony-x-to-work-on-new-album-after-touring-this-summer|title=SYMPHONY X To Work On New Album After Touring This Summer|date=June 25, 2019|website=Metalinjection.net}}</ref>

=== Upcoming tenth studio album (2020–present) ===
During bassist LePond's May 2020 interview with Metal Nation when asked about plans for him and the band, he had confirmed that the band was ready to start writing the tenth studio album, a follow-up to their 2015 album, ''[[Underworld (Symphony X album)|Underworld]]'' as soon as the [[COVID-19 pandemic|virus]] slowed down, and that writing would begin in about 'a month or so'.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.blabbermouth.net/news/symphony-x-is-ready-to-start-writing-a-new-album/|title=SYMPHONY X Is 'Ready To Start Writing' A New Album|publisher=Blabbermouth|date=May 8, 2020|access-date=May 8, 2020}}</ref>

==Solo projects==
Keyboardist [[Michael Pinnella]] released a solo album, entitled ''[[Enter by the Twelfth Gate]]'', on October 12, 2004.<ref name="amazon1">{{cite web | url = https://www.amazon.com/Enter-Twelfth-Gate-Michael-Pinnella/dp/B00031R810 | title = Enter By the Twelfth Gate: Michael Pinella | website = Amazon | access-date = February 18, 2009 | date = December 22, 2004}}</ref> Another solo album, "Ascension", was released in 2014.<ref name="ascension">{{cite web | url = https://www.amazon.com/Ascension-Michael-Pinnella/dp/B00R1ZZBAG | title = Ascension: Michael Pinella | website = Amazon | access-date = July 9, 2015 | date = December 16, 2014}}</ref>

Vocalist [[Russell Allen]]'s solo debut, entitled ''[[Atomic Soul]]'', was released in the summer of 2005. With this album, Allen took a different musical direction from that seen in his work with Symphony X. It was considered by many—including Allen himself—to be a [[hard rock]] album.<ref name="progressiveworld">{{cite web | url = http://www.progressiveworld.net/allenrinterv.html | title = A Little Bit O' (Atomic) Soul - An Interview With Russell Allen | access-date = February 18, 2009 | author = Turner, Joshua | date = June 3, 2005 | website=Progressiveworld.net | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080719073306/http://www.progressiveworld.net/allenrinterv.html | archive-date = July 19, 2008 | url-status = dead}}</ref> Also in 2005, he recorded an album called ''[[The Battle (Allen/Lande album)|The Battle]]'' with former [[Masterplan (band)|Masterplan]] vocalist [[Jørn Lande]] under the moniker "Allen/Lande".<ref name="metalrules">{{cite web | url = http://www.metal-rules.com/zine/content/view/411/62/ | title = Russell Allen of Allen/Lande | access-date = February 18, 2009 | author = Sandvall, Anders | date = November 11, 2005 | publisher = metal-rules.com | url-status = dead | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080828064726/http://www.metal-rules.com/zine/content/view/411/62/ | archive-date = August 28, 2008}}</ref> The two would later record follow-up albums entitled ''[[The Revenge (album)|The Revenge]]'', released May 11, 2007; ''[[The Showdown (album)|The Showdown]]'', released November 5, 2010; and ''[[The Great Divide (Allen/Lande album)|The Great Divide]]'', released October 21, 2014.<ref name="hardrockhideout">{{cite web | url = http://hardrockhideout.com/2007/06/21/allenlande-the-revenge-release-year-2007/ | title = Allen/Lande - The Revenge (Release Year - 2007) | access-date = February 18, 2009 | author = Rockitt, Rob | date = June 21, 2007 | publisher = hardrockhideout.com}}</ref><ref name ="thegreatdividereview">{{cite web | url = http://www.angrymetalguy.com/allenlande-great-divide-review/ | title = Allen/Lande - The Great Divide Review | access-date = November 15, 2014 | author = Druhm, Steel | date = October 8, 2014 | website=Angrymetalguy.com}}</ref>

In early 2011, Russell Allen co-founded [[heavy metal music|heavy metal]] [[supergroup (music)|supergroup]] [[Adrenaline Mob]] with guitarist [[Mike Orlando]] and drummer [[Mike Portnoy]] (ex-[[Dream Theater]]), who has since left the group.<ref name="Noisecreep">{{cite web |url=http://www.noisecreep.com/2011/06/17/mike-portnoy-adrenaline-mob-to-make-live-debut-in-new-york-cit/ |title=Mike Portnoy's Adrenaline Mob to Make Live Debut in New York City |author=Sciarretto, Amy |date=June 17, 2011 |publisher=[[Noisecreep]] |access-date=February 10, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/mike-portnoy-says-adrenaline-mob-was-not-growing-fast-enough/|title=Mike Portnoy Says Adrenaline Mob Was 'Not Growing Fast Enough' - Blabbermouth.net|work=BLABBERMOUTH.NET|date=September 24, 2013}}</ref> They have released three studio albums, ''Omertá'' (2012), ''Men of Honor'' (2014)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/adrenaline-mob-to-release-dearly-departed-album-in-february/|title=Adrenaline Mob To Release 'Dearly Departed' Album In February - Blabbermouth.net|work=BLABBERMOUTH.NET|date=January 6, 2015}}</ref> and ''We the People'' (2017).

Bassist Michael LePond released his first solo album, ''Mike LePond's Silent Assassins'' on September 26, 2014. It features guest performances from guitarist [[Mike Chlasciak]] ([[Halford (band)|Halford]], [[Testament (band)|Testament]]), lead guitarist, drum producer and Symphony X bandmate [[Michael Romeo]], and vocalist [[Alan Tecchio]] (Hades, [[Watchtower (band)|Watchtower]]). LePond himself played bass and rhythm guitar.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|title=Symphony X Bassist MIKE LEPOND To Release 'Silent Assassins' Solo Album In September|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/symphony-x-bassist-mike-lepond-to-release-silent-assassins-solo-album-in-september/|website=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|access-date=August 25, 2014|date=August 21, 2014}}</ref>

Michael Romeo's second solo album, ''[[War of the Worlds, Pt. 1]]'', was released on July 27, 2018. The album features Rick Castellano on vocals, [[John DeServio]] on bass, and [[John Macaluso]] on drums.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://blabbermouth.herokuapp.com/news/symphony-x-guitarist-michael-romeo-trailer-for-war-of-the-worlds-pt-1-solo-album/|title=SYMPHONY X Guitarist MICHAEL ROMEO: Trailer For 'War Of The Worlds / Pt. 1' Solo Album|date=July 12, 2018|website=Blabbermouth.net}}</ref> It was Romeo's first solo album since ''[[The Dark Chapter]]'', which was released in 1994. ''[[War of the Worlds, Pt. 2]]'' was released on March 25, 2022.

==Musical style==
{{expand section|date=January 2014}}
<!-- lyrical style, musical style, and influences are all important -->
Symphony X is often compared to other progressive metal bands such as [[Dream Theater]], [[Fates Warning]], and [[Shadow Gallery]].<ref name="popmatters">{{cite web | url = http://www.popmatters.com/music/reviews/f/fateswarning-awaken.shtml | title = Fates Warning: Awaken the Guardian (Expanded Edition) – PopMatters Music Review | access-date = February 18, 2009 | author = Begrand, Adrien | date = September 16, 2005 | work = PopMatters | publisher = PopMatters Media, Inc}}</ref> Their music includes complex timings and odd meters while incorporating elements of [[Heavy metal music|heavy metal]] and [[progressive rock]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.symphonyx.com/site/band/|title=Symphony X History|publisher=Symphony X Official Website}}</ref> It also contains strong neo-classical elements reminiscent of [[Yngwie Malmsteen]], [[Cacophony (band)|Cacophony]], [[Randy Rhoads]], and other bands.<ref name="FAQ-1">{{cite web | url = http://www.symphonyx.com/faq_band.html#1 | title = Official Symphony X FAQ: Who influenced each of the band members? | access-date = February 18, 2009 | publisher = symphonyx.com | date = September 2003 | url-status = dead | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090217193115/http://symphonyx.com/faq_band.html#1 | archive-date = February 17, 2009 }}</ref> The band have been categorized as [[progressive metal]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/symphony-x-mn0000000343/biography|title=Symphony X {{!}} Biography & History|last=Hill|first=Gary|website=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=February 19, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.loudersound.com/news/symphony-x-announce-european-tour-dates|title=Symphony X announce European tour dates|last=Ewing|first=Jerry|date=January 12, 2019|website=Prog Magazine|access-date=February 19, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.guitarworld.com/artists/symphony-x-mastermind-michael-romeo-talks-new-solo-album-war-of-the-worlds-pt-1|title=Symphony X Mastermind Michael Romeo Talks New Solo Album, 'War of the Worlds, Pt. 1'|last=Maxwell|first=Jackson|date=October 4, 2018|website=[[Guitar World]]|access-date=February 19, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UAYZXhzC9BMC&pg=PA80|title=Black Sabbath and Philosophy: Mastering Reality|last=Irwin|first=William|date=2012|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=9781118397596|page=80}}</ref> [[power metal]],<ref name="MIPL">{{cite web|url=http://www.metalinjection.net/tbt/get-classical-with-the-brilliantly-executed-paradise-lost-by-symphony-x|title=#TBT: Get Classical with the Brilliantly Executed Paradise Lost by SYMPHONY X|last=Mercer|first=Lauryn|date=April 12, 2018|website=Metalinjection.net|access-date=February 19, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rQPph_5WKJ4C&pg=PA27|title=CMJ New Music Report|last=Sciarretto|first=Amy|date=November 17, 2003|publisher=CMJ Network, Inc.|page=27}}</ref> and [[neoclassical metal]].<ref name="MIPL"/><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nPmADwAAQBAJ&pg=PA546|title=The Rock History Reader|last=Cateforis|first=Theo|date=2019|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781315394800|page=546}}</ref>

== Recording studio: The Dungeon==
The Dungeon is the studio located at the home of Symphony X's guitarist and composer [[Michael Romeo]]. The albums ''[[The Divine Wings of Tragedy]]'' and ''[[V – The New Mythology Suite|V: The New Mythology Suite]]'' were partially recorded in the Dungeon, while ''[[The Odyssey (album)|The Odyssey]]'', ''[[Paradise Lost (Symphony X album)|Paradise Lost]]'', ''[[Iconoclast (Symphony X album)|Iconoclast]]'' and ''[[Underworld (Symphony X album)|Underworld]]'' were fully recorded there and produced by Romeo himself.

== Line-up ==
'''Current members'''
* [[Michael Romeo]] − guitars, backing vocals (1994–present)
* [[Michael Pinnella]] − keyboards, backing vocals (1994–present)
* [[Jason Rullo]] – drums (1994–1997, 1998–present)
* [[Russell Allen]] − lead vocals (1995–present)
* [[Michael Lepond]] − bass, backing vocals (1999–present)

'''Former members'''
* [[Thomas Miller (bassist)|Thomas Miller]] − bass, backing vocals (1994−1998)
* Rod Tyler − lead vocals (1994)
* Thomas Walling − drums (1997−1998)
